subject: Fwd: [bostonnewtech] Boston New Technology Meetup News and Upcoming Events
bodyText:
Begin forwarded message:

> From: Chris Requena <chris@mobinett.com>
> Subject: [bostonnewtech] Boston New Technology Meetup News and Upcoming Events
> Date: April 30, 2014 at 3:09:47 PM EDT
> To: bostonnewtech-announce@meetup.com
> Reply-To: chris@mobinett.com
> 
> Hello Boston New Technologists,
> 
> Please join us for our next technology product showcase Tuesday, May 20th at 6 pm at Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology in Boston! Get all the details and update your RSVP here. As always, you must RSVP as "Yes" to attend (no walk-ins/guests allowed).
> 
> Also, we invite you to the inaugural event for the 2014 Innovation Cities Tour, on Monday, May 12 at 6pm at the IBM Innovation Center in Cambridge. Hosted by Innovation Excellence, the Disruptor Foundation and Hype Innovation. Get all the details and update your RSVP here.
> 
> We look forward to seeing you!
> 
> -- Learn About Our Sponsors --
> 
>  
> 
>  
> Foley Hoag LLP - No industry moves faster or makes a bigger impact on the way we live than the technology industry. Technology innovators in software, hardware, gaming, entertainment and telecom turn to Foley Hoag LLP to help secure and maintain their leadership positions in this competitive industry. Our attorneys provide a comprehensive array of legal services for companies in all stages of development, from conception through profitability and beyond. For more information, please click here to visit our website for technology entrepreneurs. www.FoleyHoag.com 1-617-832-1000
> 
>  
> 
> 
> Innovation Excellence - The Innovation Excellence 2014 Innovation Cities Tour celebrates the Innovation Movement across the US  – by capturing, sharing and spreading your stories. Our goal is to highlight innovation and innovators in each city we visit, proving that innovation is now a full-fledged discipline. We are gathering together disruptive thinkers, doers, technologies, and resources from the Innovation Excellence community in order to inspire one another, share knowledge, discover new resources, and accelerate innovation in New York, BOSTON, San Francisco, Chicago and beyond. For more information, visit http://innovationexcellence.com.
> 
>  
> 
> 
> Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology - BFIT is non-profit, technical private college with approximately 500 students founded in 1908 in Boston’s South End neighborhood. With the goal of investing in the human capital of our state, BFIT is addressing the skills gap crisis facing the US by helping a largely underserved population SKILL UP as technicians for the fields that drive our nation’s economy. The College offers an array of programs leading to careers in Automotive Technology, Computer Technology, Biomedical Engineering Technology, Health Information Technology, Electronics Engineering Technology, Mechanical Engineering Technology, Building Technology & Design, HVAC&R, Electrical Technology, and Eye Health Technology through certificate, associate, and bachelor degree credentials. The College is accredited by the New England Association of Schools and Colleges (NEASC). Additional information and videos about the College and its programs can be found online at www.bfit.edu.
> 
>  
> 
> -- Special Announcements --
> 
> TEC@FoleyHoag event on May 14
> 
> At the next TEC@FoleyHoag event on May 14, author and CEO Andy Coville will walk attendees through her framework for developing new products that customers want to own, use, spend money on, talk about, and embrace as part of their identities. Coville calls it relevant innovation, to which she devoted significant space in her new book: “Relevance: The Power to Change Minds and Behavior and Stay Ahead of the Competition.” Wednesday, May 14, 6:00 pm – 8:00 pm. Foley Hoag, 155 Seaport Boulevard, Boston, MA RSVP
>  
>  
> Innovation Excellence 2014 Innovation Cities Tour comes to Boston!
>  
> Boston New Technology invites you to the inaugural event for the 2014 Innovation Cities Tour, on Monday, May 12, at the IBM Innovation Center in Cambridge, hosted by Innovation Excellence, the Disruptor Foundation and Hype Innovation! Join us as we celebrate the Innovation Movement across the US by capturing, sharing, and spreading your stories. We are gathering together disruptive thinkers, doers, technologies, and resources from the Innovation Excellence community in order to inspire one another, share knowledge, discover new resources, and accelerate innovation in your city -- and beyond. RSVP Today - Admission is Free & Space is Limited.
>  
> Google Glass Lightning Talks looking for Speakers! 
>  
> GDG Boston/Cambridge members really appreciate talks by other members about their software development experience and we're looking for speakers of all experience levels.  You don't need to be a professional Glass or Android developer. If you would like to give a talk (and you know you would!), please send a note to praveen.aravamudham@gmail.com with a few details. When submitting, please describe the purpose of your Glass app(s), include an explanation if your app was built for commercial purposes, research or just for fun, and explain if you built your Glass app was built using the Glass API or the Mirror API.  If built using the mirror API, which platform was used to build the app? (PHP, Python, C#, etc.).
>  
> 
> #BNT40 Presentation Videos
> 
> Did you miss our last Showcase? Learn about our great presenters and their products on our YouTube Page!
> 
> New Website
> 
> Check out our brand new http://www.BostonNewTech.org website! We are excited to launch this new channel as another outlet to highlight our events and content (blogs/photos/videos) and to promote our presenters and sponsors! 
> 
> Sponsors and Venues Needed for BNT
> 
> Interested in sponsoring Boston New Tech or offering venue space for 150+ attendees? Please Contact the Organizers.
> 
>  Join BNT on Social Media
> 
> Please follow @BostonNewTech on twitter, like Boston New Tech on facebook and subscribe to our YouTube channel to access videos from all our showcase events.
> 
>  
> 
>  -- Recommended Events --
> 
> 5/5 6:00 pm -- Mobile Monday presents Mobile Healthcare 2014 -- District Hall, Boston, MA. Free. RSVP.
> 
> 5/6 7:00 pm -- BNT & IEEE Boston ENET - Raising Money from Crowdfunding Panel – Registration Now Open! -- Constant Contact, 3rd Floor, The Great Room, 1601 Trapelo Rd. Waltham, MA. RSVP.
> 
> 5/6 8:00 am -- Boston TechBreakfast: Inwiter, 1sqbox, Eventuosity, RedBerrRy, and More! -- Microsoft NERD- Horace Mann Room, 1 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP.
> 
> 5/6 6:30 pm -- Intro to the Boston Startup Community -- GA Boston (WeWork), Boston, MA. Free. RSVP.
> 
> 5/6 6:30 pm -- Break the Bubble: Tips & Tricks for Entering Boston’s Tech Ecosystem -- ONEin3 Boston, Boston, MA. Free RSVP.
> 
> 5/7 9:30 am -- Jobs Act Update: Proposed Rules for “Mini-IPOs” Under Regulation A+ -- Cambridge Innovation Center, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP.
> 
> 5/8 7:00 pm -- IBM Watson Ecosystem Meetup Group -- IBM Innovation Center, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP.
> 
> 5/10 -- StartupJackpot is coming to Boston! Startups compete to win a bunch of no-strings cash, prizes, and accelerator spots. Apply today with promo code BostonNewTech for 20% off tickets! 
> 
> 5/11 - 5/18 -- Together Boston - An annual celebration of music, art and technology, based in Cambridge, MA. Register with promo code: BMM14 for pass discount.
> 
> 5/12 6:00 pm – Innovation Excellence 2014 Cities Tour – IBM Innovation Center, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP. 
> 
> 5/13 6:30 pm -- CoFoundersLab Matchup Boston -- WeWork Seaport, 51 Melcher St, Boston. Free. RSVP.
> 
> 5/14 6:00 pm -- Mass Innovation Nights MIN62 -- Progressive Software, 14 Oak Park Drive, Bedford, MA. RSVP.
> 
> 5/16 6:00 pm – TEC@Foley Hoag, To innovate well, make sure you are relevant. Author and CEO Andy Coville speaks on her book Relevance: The Power to Change Minds and Behavior and Stay Ahead of the Competition. – Foley Hoag, 155 Seaport Boulevard, Boston, MA. RSVP.
> 
> 5/20 6:00 pm – Boston New Technology May 2014 Product Showcase #BNT41 – Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology, Boston, MA. Free. RSVP.
> 
> 5/29 - 5/30 -- TiECONEAST: the largest startup conf on East Coast. This year’s theme is #BreakingBoundaries! Cambridge Marriott. Register now with: PROMO CODE: TC14AP
> 
> 6/10 -- Xconomy’s Xponential Cities Series: Boston 2034 -- Seaport World Trade Center, 200 Seaport Blvd, Boston, MA. Register now!
> 
> To see our latest complete list of events, visit us here.
> 
>  
> 
> Thank you,
> 
> The BNT Team
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --
> This message was sent by Chris Requena (chris@mobinett.com) from Boston New Technology Meetup Group.
> To learn more about Chris Requena, visit his/her member profile
> To report this message or block the sender, please click here
> To unsubscribe from special announcements from your Organizer(s), click here 
> 
> Meetup, POB 4668 #37895 NY NY USA 10163 | support@meetup.com
bodyHtml:
Begin forwarded message:

From: Chris Requena <chris@mobinett.com>
Subject: [bostonnewtech] Boston New Technology Meetup News and Upcoming Events
Date: April 30, 2014 at 3:09:47 PM EDT
To: bostonnewtech-announce@meetup.com
Reply-To: chris@mobinett.com

Hello Boston New Technologists,

Please join us for our next technology product showcase Tuesday, May 20th at 6 pm at Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology in Boston! Get all the details and update your RSVP here. As always, you must RSVP as "Yes" to attend (no walk-ins/guests allowed).

Also, we invite you to the inaugural event for the 2014 Innovation Cities Tour, on Monday, May 12 at 6pm at the IBM Innovation Center in Cambridge. Hosted by Innovation Excellence, the Disruptor Foundation and Hype Innovation. Get all the details and update your RSVP here.

We look forward to seeing you!

-- Learn About Our Sponsors --

 

 

Foley Hoag LLP - No industry moves faster or makes a bigger impact on the way we live than the technology industry. Technology innovators in software, hardware, gaming, entertainment and telecom turn to Foley Hoag LLP to help secure and maintain their leadership positions in this competitive industry. Our attorneys provide a comprehensive array of legal services for companies in all stages of development, from conception through profitability and beyond. For more information, please click here to visit our website for technology entrepreneurs. www.FoleyHoag.com 1-617-832-1000

 

Innovation Excellence - The Innovation Excellence 2014 Innovation Cities Tour celebrates the Innovation Movement across the US  – by capturing, sharing and spreading your stories. Our goal is to highlight innovation and innovators in each city we visit, proving that innovation is now a full-fledged discipline. We are gathering together disruptive thinkers, doers, technologies, and resources from the Innovation Excellence community in order to inspire one another, share knowledge, discover new resources, and accelerate innovation in New York, BOSTON, San Francisco, Chicago and beyond. For more information, visit http://innovationexcellence.com.

 

Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology - BFIT is non-profit, technical private college with approximately 500 students founded in 1908 in Boston’s South End neighborhood. With the goal of investing in the human capital of our state, BFIT is addressing the skills gap crisis facing the US by helping a largely underserved population SKILL UP as technicians for the fields that drive our nation’s economy. The College offers an array of programs leading to careers in Automotive Technology, Computer Technology, Biomedical Engineering Technology, Health Information Technology, Electronics Engineering Technology, Mechanical Engineering Technology, Building Technology & Design, HVAC&R, Electrical Technology, and Eye Health Technology through certificate, associate, and bachelor degree credentials. The College is accredited by the New England Association of Schools and Colleges (NEASC). Additional information and videos about the College and its programs can be found online at www.bfit.edu.

 

-- Special Announcements --

TEC@FoleyHoag event on May 14

At the next TEC@FoleyHoag event on May 14, author and CEO Andy Coville will walk attendees through her framework for developing new products that customers want to own, use, spend money on, talk about, and embrace as part of their identities. Coville calls it relevant innovation, to which she devoted significant space in her new book: “Relevance: The Power to Change Minds and Behavior and Stay Ahead of the Competition.” Wednesday, May 14, 6:00 pm – 8:00 pm. Foley Hoag, 155 Seaport Boulevard, Boston, MA RSVP

 

 

Innovation Excellence 2014 Innovation Cities Tour comes to Boston!
 
Boston New Technology invites you to the inaugural event for the 2014 Innovation Cities Tour, on Monday, May 12, at the IBM Innovation Center in Cambridge, hosted by Innovation Excellence, the Disruptor Foundation and Hype Innovation! Join us as we celebrate the Innovation Movement across the US by capturing, sharing, and spreading your stories. We are gathering together disruptive thinkers, doers, technologies, and resources from the Innovation Excellence community in order to inspire one another, share knowledge, discover new resources, and accelerate innovation in your city -- and beyond. RSVP Today - Admission is Free & Space is Limited.

 

Google Glass Lightning Talks looking for Speakers! 

 

GDG Boston/Cambridge members really appreciate talks by other members about their software development experience and we're looking for speakers of all experience levels.  You don't need to be a professional Glass or Android developer. If you would like to give a talk (and you know you would!), please send a note to praveen.aravamudham@gmail.com with a few details. When submitting, please describe the purpose of your Glass app(s), include an explanation if your app was built for commercial purposes, research or just for fun, and explain if you built your Glass app was built using the Glass API or the Mirror API.  If built using the mirror API, which platform was used to build the app? (PHP, Python, C#, etc.).

 

#BNT40 Presentation Videos

Did you miss our last Showcase? Learn about our great presenters and their products on our YouTube Page!

New Website

Check out our brand new http://www.BostonNewTech.org website! We are excited to launch this new channel as another outlet to highlight our events and content (blogs/photos/videos) and to promote our presenters and sponsors! 

Sponsors and Venues Needed for BNT

Interested in sponsoring Boston New Tech or offering venue space for 150+ attendees? Please Contact the Organizers.

 Join BNT on Social Media

Please follow @BostonNewTech on twitter, like Boston New Tech on facebook and subscribe to our YouTube channel to access videos from all our showcase events.

 

 -- Recommended Events --

5/5 6:00 pm -- Mobile Monday presents Mobile Healthcare 2014 -- District Hall, Boston, MA. Free. RSVP.

5/6 7:00 pm -- BNT & IEEE Boston ENET - Raising Money from Crowdfunding Panel – Registration Now Open! -- Constant Contact, 3rd Floor, The Great Room, 1601 Trapelo Rd. Waltham, MA. RSVP.

5/6 8:00 am -- Boston TechBreakfast: Inwiter, 1sqbox, Eventuosity, RedBerrRy, and More! -- Microsoft NERD- Horace Mann Room, 1 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP.

5/6 6:30 pm -- Intro to the Boston Startup Community -- GA Boston (WeWork), Boston, MA. Free. RSVP.

5/6 6:30 pm -- Break the Bubble: Tips & Tricks for Entering Boston’s Tech Ecosystem -- ONEin3 Boston, Boston, MA. Free RSVP.

5/7 9:30 am -- Jobs Act Update: Proposed Rules for “Mini-IPOs” Under Regulation A+ -- Cambridge Innovation Center, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP.

5/8 7:00 pm -- IBM Watson Ecosystem Meetup Group -- IBM Innovation Center, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP.

5/10 -- StartupJackpot is coming to Boston! Startups compete to win a bunch of no-strings cash, prizes, and accelerator spots. Apply today with promo code BostonNewTech for 20% off tickets! 

5/11 - 5/18 -- Together Boston - An annual celebration of music, art and technology, based in Cambridge, MA. Register with promo code: BMM14 for pass discount.

5/12 6:00 pm – Innovation Excellence 2014 Cities Tour – IBM Innovation Center, Cambridge, MA. Free. RSVP.

5/13 6:30 pm -- CoFoundersLab Matchup Boston -- WeWork Seaport, 51 Melcher St, Boston. Free. RSVP.

5/14 6:00 pm -- Mass Innovation Nights MIN62 -- Progressive Software, 14 Oak Park Drive, Bedford, MA. RSVP.

5/16 6:00 pm – TEC@Foley Hoag, To innovate well, make sure you are relevant. Author and CEO Andy Coville speaks on her book Relevance: The Power to Change Minds and Behavior and Stay Ahead of the Competition. – Foley Hoag, 155 Seaport Boulevard, Boston, MA. RSVP.

5/20 6:00 pm – Boston New Technology May 2014 Product Showcase #BNT41 – Benjamin Franklin Institute of Technology, Boston, MA. Free. RSVP.

5/29 - 5/30 -- TiECONEAST: the largest startup conf on East Coast. This year’s theme is #BreakingBoundaries! Cambridge Marriott. Register now with: PROMO CODE: TC14AP

6/10 -- Xconomy’s Xponential Cities Series: Boston 2034 -- Seaport World Trade Center, 200 Seaport Blvd, Boston, MA. Register now!

To see our latest complete list of events, visit us here.

 

Thank you,

The BNT Team





--
This message was sent by Chris Requena (chris@mobinett.com) from Boston New Technology Meetup Group.
To learn more about Chris Requena, visit his/her member profile

subject: Re: [PyLadies-Boston] PyLadies May News
bodyText:
On May 7, 2014, at 1:46 PM, Jennifer Konikowski <jmkoni@icloud.com> wrote:

> Hey y'all!
> 
> Happy first birthday to PyLadies Boston! We have a lot going on right now and it is pretty exciting.
> 
> State of PyLadies (May Monthly Meeting) - Monday, May 19, 7-9pm @Akamai - This is a big meetup for us. We're one year old as a group and we want to make sure we grow in the direction that y'all want us to grow. If you have an idea for a presentation, hack day, or any other meetup type, come and tell us! This will be a quick presentation (~10 min) on what we've done in the past year, then a roundtable discussion about what we want the next year to look like.
> Beginner Project Afternoon - we're alternating Saturdays and Sundays from 2-4pm at coffee shops in Kendall. Check the meetup description for where we'll be. This Saturday, we'll be meeting at Area 4 Cafe (right next to the restaurant).
> Speech & Messaging API Coding Workshop - Tuesday, May 20 - AT&T is putting on a workshop to use speech and messaging APIs. It is completely free and they have both day long and evening only sessions. Register here for all day and here for the evening one.
> Boston Python May Project Night - Monday, May 12, 6:30-9pm @NERD - Spots are still available! If you need some extra project time beyond the two hours of the beginner afternoons, come join us. Sassa, Michelle, possibly Margaret & I will all be there, in addition to a ton of other people who would be more than happy to help out.
> We're doing lightning talks for the June meeting. Got 5-10 minutes of python related stuff that you want to talk about? Email me!
> FREE BOOK! - Jeff Knupp has offered to give away digital copies of his book Idiomatic Python to any female engineer. Feel free to email him directly, or email me and I will send him one large email with all of our email addresses. Read more here.
> See y'all soon!
> 
> Jennifer
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --
> This message was sent by Jennifer Konikowski (jmkoni@icloud.com) from PyLadies Boston.
> To learn more about Jennifer Konikowski, visit his/her member profile
> To report this message or block the sender, please click here
> To unsubscribe from special announcements from your Organizer(s), click here 
> 
> Meetup, POB 4668 #37895 NY NY USA 10163 | support@meetup.com
bodyHtml:
On May 7, 2014, at 1:46 PM, Jennifer Konikowski <jmkoni@icloud.com> wrote:

Hey y'all!

Happy first birthday to PyLadies Boston! We have a lot going on right now and it is pretty exciting.

  • State of PyLadies (May Monthly Meeting) - Monday, May 19, 7-9pm @Akamai - This is a big meetup for us. We're one year old as a group and we want to make sure we grow in the direction that y'all want us to grow. If you have an idea for a presentation, hack day, or any other meetup type, come and tell us! This will be a quick presentation (~10 min) on what we've done in the past year, then a roundtable discussion about what we want the next year to look like.
  • Beginner Project Afternoon - we're alternating Saturdays and Sundays from 2-4pm at coffee shops in Kendall. Check the meetup description for where we'll be. This Saturday, we'll be meeting at Area 4 Cafe (right next to the restaurant).
  • Speech & Messaging API Coding Workshop - Tuesday, May 20 - AT&T is putting on a workshop to use speech and messaging APIs. It is completely free and they have both day long and evening only sessions. Register here for all day and here for the evening one.
  • Boston Python May Project Night - Monday, May 12, 6:30-9pm @NERD - Spots are still available! If you need some extra project time beyond the two hours of the beginner afternoons, come join us. Sassa, Michelle, possibly Margaret & I will all be there, in addition to a ton of other people who would be more than happy to help out.
  • We're doing lightning talks for the June meeting. Got 5-10 minutes of python related stuff that you want to talk about? Email me!
  • FREE BOOK! - Jeff Knupp has offered to give away digital copies of his book Idiomatic Python to any female engineer. Feel free to email him directly, or email me and I will send him one large email with all of our email addresses. Read more here.

See y'all soon!

Jennifer





--
This message was sent by Jennifer Konikowski (jmkoni@icloud.com) from PyLadies Boston.
To learn more about Jennifer Konikowski, visit his/her member profile

Join us in celebrating  Israel @ 66 by attending a “Made In Israel” demo event May 6, 7pm at the Oshman Family JCC, Palo Alto.
On the evening of May 6th, we'll be holding a special event celebrating some of the new technologies developed by Israelis
This is a unique opportunity to learn more about the exciting innovations by local Israeli founders and to make valuable connections with key players in the industry.
There will be 5 startups giving brief pitches who will then be available for further discussion and demos.

subject: UCSF Alumni Weekend Invitation
bodyText:
http://www.ucsfalumni.org/redirect.aspx?linkID=7107&eid=176631&puid=ed2d3e0e-6fea-4ec5-9171-571cf439bca7
The UCSF  Office of Alumni Relations would like to invite Coursera Course enrollees to  join us for Alumni Weekend 2014 on May 29-31 as we celebrate the 150th  anniversary of UCSF. In particular, we would love to see you at the following  events during the Weekend: Osher Center’s  Mini Medical School for the Public: Eating for Health (and Pleasure): The UCSF  Guide to Good Nutrition—($85)- Friday, May 30, 7:30am  – 12:00pm at Mission Bay, N-114, Genentech HallAll-Alumni  Kickoff Reception Featuring Lavay Smith and Her Red Hot Skillet Lickers – Friday, May 30, 6:30pm  – 8:30pm at the Palace HotelThe  Chancellor’s Breakfast Featuring the State of the University and a History  Roundtable Moderated by Michael Krasny – Saturday, May 31, 8:00am – 9:30am at the Palace HotelRoundtable participants include Nancy Ascher, MD, PhD;  Henry Bourne, MD; Troy Daniels, DDS, MS; Bob Day, PharmD; and Marilyn Flood,  RN, PhDDiscovery  Talks – Saturday, May 31,  10:00am – 11:30am at the Palace HotelSpeakers include Esteban Burchard, MD, MPH; Barbara  Drew, RN, PhD, FAAN, FAHA; Shari Dworkin, PhD, MS; Cynthia Kenyon, PhD; Shingo  Kajimura, PhD; and Tracy McKnight, PhD, Postdoctoral Scholar Alumna.
Space is  limited. To RSVP for these events please contact Denise Leong at mailto:dleong@support.ucsf.edu and provide  the following information with your response:
NameDepartment/UCSF  affiliationEvents  you wish to attendEmail  address

http://www.ucsfalumni.org/redirect.aspx?linkID=7106&eid=176631             > http://www.ucsfalumni.org/redirect.aspx?linkID=7105&eid=176631&authkey=mk8A2f3Yzk2KOsXs5jKBEMdcEeIDxUrBRy8PtRugUPfD63iePR%2bTxA%3d%3d             > http://www.ucsfalumni.org/redirect.aspx?linkID=7104&eid=176631             > http://www.ucsfalumni.org/redirect.aspx?linkID=7103&eid=176631             > http://www.ucsfalumni.org/redirect.aspx?linkID=7102&eid=176631Please contact Denise Leong atmailto:dleong@support.ucsf.edu or  415.476.6334 with any questions regarding registration.
UCSF Alumni Association - Box 0248
University of California, San Francisco
San Francisco, CA 94143-0248
If you wish to be removed from this group's mailing list, http://www.ucsfalumni.org/?sid=1420&gid=1&pgid=37&cid=51&seiid=644&ecatid=20&puid=ed2d3e0e-6fea-4ec5-9171-571cf439bca7.
bodyHtml:
View this email in a web page


The UCSF Office of Alumni Relations would like to invite Coursera Course enrollees to join us for Alumni Weekend 2014 on May 29-31 as we celebrate the 150th anniversary of UCSF. In particular, we would love to see you at the following events during the Weekend: 

  • Osher Center’s Mini Medical School for the Public: Eating for Health (and Pleasure): The UCSF Guide to Good Nutrition—($85)- Friday, May 30, 7:30am – 12:00pm at Mission Bay, N-114, Genentech Hall
  • All-Alumni Kickoff Reception Featuring Lavay Smith and Her Red Hot Skillet Lickers – Friday, May 30, 6:30pm – 8:30pm at the Palace Hotel
  • The Chancellor’s Breakfast Featuring the State of the University and a History Roundtable Moderated by Michael Krasny – Saturday, May 31, 8:00am – 9:30am at the Palace Hotel
    • Roundtable participants include Nancy Ascher, MD, PhD; Henry Bourne, MD; Troy Daniels, DDS, MS; Bob Day, PharmD; and Marilyn Flood, RN, PhD
  • Discovery Talks – Saturday, May 31, 10:00am – 11:30am at the Palace Hotel
    • Speakers include Esteban Burchard, MD, MPH; Barbara Drew, RN, PhD, FAAN, FAHA; Shari Dworkin, PhD, MS; Cynthia Kenyon, PhD; Shingo Kajimura, PhD; and Tracy McKnight, PhD, Postdoctoral Scholar Alumna.

Space is limited. To RSVP for these events please contact Denise Leong at dleong@support.ucsf.edu and provide the following information with your response:

Name
Department/UCSF affiliation
Events you wish to attend
Email address


> RSVP here!
> Palace Hotel
> Schedule
> Logistics

Please contact Denise Leong at dleong@
support.ucsf.edu or 415.476.6334 with any questions regarding registration.

UCSF Alumni Association - Box 0248
University of California, San Francisco
San Francisco, CA 94143-0248

subject: Lunch Talk: How to Incorporate Writing into your Career (4/15/15 from 12-1pm)
bodyText:
How to Incorporate Writing into your Career

The Beat at BUSM proudly presents a talk by Dr. George Annas, JD, MPH, a prominent writer and professor at BUSM, BUSPH, and BULaw. At this lunch talk, Dr. Annas will speak about his own career writing about medical issues, as well as his advice to students on how to get their writing published. This talk is open to all BUSM students and faculty.

When: Tuesday 04/15/14 from noon to 1pm
Where: R103
What: How to incorporate writing into your career.

Non-Pizza food will be served

This will be the first lunch talk hosted by The Beat, a newly founded student-run journal at BUSM. Our first issue will be released in May.

For more info on Dr. Annas, please visit:
http://www.bu.edu/sph/profile/george-annas/

Hope to see you there!
The Beat at BUSM

subject: [Boston-Predictive-Analytics] New Event:  Gradient Boosted Regression Trees
bodyHtml:
Hi Folks,

Last summer following PyData Boston we created a spin-off Meetup group for Python + Data Science given there is growing interest in this area.

http://www.meetup.com/PyData-Boston/

Next Wednesday Peter Prettenhofer of DataRobot will be giving a talk on Gradient Boosted Regression Trees (GBRT) which is a powerful statistical learning technique with applications in a variety of areas, ranging from web page ranking to environmental niche modeling.  He will be using Python's scikit-learn to apply the technique to various examples. Please see the following event page for more info.

http://www.meetup.com/PyData-Boston/events/171874092/

Please note the talk will include a mathematical front-end, and so for non-Python users this may be of help.  For R-Users, there are various R-libraries, such as gbm, brt, dismo, that pertain to this analytic technique.  Some of the R-bloggers articles may be of help, too.

http://www.r-bloggers.com/?s=gradient+boosted

 

Best Regards,

John





--
This message was sent by John Verostek (johnverostek@gmail.com) from Boston Predictive Analytics.
To learn more about John Verostek, visit his/her member profile
To report this message or block the sender, please click here
To unsubscribe from special announcements from your Organizer(s), click here

Meetup, POB 4668 #37895 NY NY USA 10163 | support@meetup.com

subject: NEW CEIT Teaching Talks!
bodyText:
Boston University Center for Excellence and Innovation in Teaching


CEIT Teaching Talks and Teaching Tech Talks
The Center for Excellence and Innovation in Teaching is pleased to offer a variety of Teaching Talks and Teaching Tech Talks during the Spring 2014 semester.  Teaching Talks will focus primarily on pedagogy, while Teaching Tech Talks will dive deeper into the use of technology to enhance teaching. All Talks are one hour and 15 minutes long and are held in the Kenmore Conference Room located on the 9th floor of 1 Silber Way.
Please reserve your space by clicking here<http://www.bu.edu/phpbin/training/register/index.php?admingroup_id=51>.
Schedule:
Tuesday, March 18
Student Work on the Web: Comparing Tools: Amod Lele, IS&T, 10:30-11:45 am
Many professors now use the convenience of the web to receive student assignments - and sometimes to give those assignments a larger audience in the wider world. But professors now have a wide range of tools with which to do this: just among the tools BU supports, the list includes Blackboard, Digication (ePortfolio), WordPress and Google Sites. This talk will help you navigate this landscape and figure out which tool is most appropriate for student work in your classrooms.
Rubrics Cubed: Making Learning Outcomes Transparent for Teachers and Students: Deborah Breen, CAS, and Kacie Cleary, IS&T, 12:00-1:15 pm
This is a teaching and tech talk combined: Co-presenters Dr. Deborah Breen (CAS Writing Program) and Kacie Cleary (Educational Technology) will take you through three important aspects of understanding and developing assessment rubrics for your class. First, we’ll discuss where rubrics fit as an assessment tool in our current approach to transparency in teaching: that is, how do they benefit teachers and how do we choose the best rubric among the different forms available? Second, we’ll consider how rubrics fit in our framework of learning-centered education:  that is, how do they benefit students before, during, and after their assessment task? (It’s not all rah rah rubrics! We’ll also talk about some of the criticisms of these assessment tools.) And finally, how does Blackboard support the development of specific rubric types through its design tools? We’ll have plenty of examples to show, so please join us for this pedagogy and practice talk.
Wednesday, March 26
Copyright in the Classroom: Dennis Hart, Office of the General Counsel, 10:30-11:45 am
Dennis Hart, Associate General Counsel, will guide us on a tour of copyright and its effect on both teachers and students in the classroom. As educators, we create copyrightable works and also rely on the copyrightable works of others. How far does the doctrine of “fair use” take us? This talk will explore the legal basics of copyright, the limits of fair use, the risks of infringement and the establishment of best practices amidst legal precedents that one court has described as “so flexible as virtually to defy definition.”  That flexibility can seem like a curse, but, if thoughtfully handled, can serve as a blessing as we consider the nagging question: do I need permission to use this?
Read & Write Gold: Universal Design Comes to Boston University: Lorraine Norwich, Office of Disability Services, and Pam Andrews, IS&T, 12:00-1:15 pm
Read and Write Gold is Universal designed software by Texthelp Inc. that helps students to read, write, self-edit and tools for study skills, research and organization.  It is available to all students at Boston University who have a user name and Kerberos password.
BU Today article: http://www.bu.edu/today/2012/reading-made-easier/
NEW DATE! Monday, March 31

The Many Uses of ePortfolios: Amod Lele, IS&T, 12:00-1:15 pm

Many programs at BU now use ePortfolios – websites that make learning visible – and they use them in very different ways. In this talk, you’ll hear about the many different ways that ePortfolios can be and are being used at BU, including student reflection within and across courses, self-presentation to employers and graduate schools, program assessment and tenure review.
Tuesday, April 8

NEW! Moving Towards Anti Racist Teaching: Sophie Godley, SPH, 10:30-11:45 am

Over the past year, I have been working to more explicitly address racism in my teaching.  This has included a training for other faculty on addressing racial micro-aggressions in the classroom, incorporating explicit expectations about health disparities during orientations for the BU School of Public Health, and creating more specific space in the classroom to address race and racism. Students report seeking out opportunities to speak and learn more about race and racism. In this Teaching Talk, I will present three approaches I have tried over the past year to more effectively address race and racism in teaching.  These ideas will hopefully be useful for other faculty as they consider their own journey.
Monday, April 14

NEW! Time Management and Positive Mindset: Guiding Students Towards Improved Academic Performance: Bruno Frustace, MED, 12:00-1:15 pm

Despite years of schooling, many students are seldom taught how best to learn and why learning strategies work.  This presentation focuses on two core components of academic success:  time-management and mindsets.  For time-management, the following will be reviewed:  1) relevant research, 2) why we procrastinate, and 3) how to battle procrastination.  Likewise, for mindsets:  1) self-efficacy, 2) stereotype threat, and 3) growth vs. fixed mindsets.  Additionally, basic steps on how students may properly manage their time will be listed.  The objective is for faculty members to acquire this knowledge and to share it with their students.  The simplicity and importance of this presentation has the capacity to quickly and positively influence the academic success of students across nearly all disciplines.
NEW! First Time in the College Classroom: Tips for New Faculty: MinHye Kim, CAS, 1:30-2:45 pm

Teaching for the first time can be overwhelming, as guidelines can be insufficient and new instructors are sometimes unaware of the potential for certain circumstances to arise. This presentation covers technical and pedagogical issues new instructors may face when teaching for the first time in the college classroom. Issues to be addressed in this Teaching Talk were selected based on 56 accumulated journals, written after teaching a foreign language course in the Modern Languages and Comparative Literature department.
Thursday, April 24
Introducing NVivo for the Mac: Amod Lele, IS&T, 10:30-11:45 am
NVivo, the powerful tool for analyzing large amounts of qualitative data, has until recently only been available for Windows. This spring and summer, the Mac version will become available. Come and see a live demo of how qualitative data analysis can work on the Mac.
What to Do Over the Summer with Blackboard Learn: Kacie Cleary, IS&T, 12:00-1:15 pm
Before putting on those flip-flops and heading off to the beach, come learn how you can do a little spring cleaning of your Blackboard course to get yourself ready for the fall. This session will present strategies that you can use to clean up old documents, organize new ones and utilize some new tools and features. Just think, your fall semester will be off to the right start with an organized Blackboard course before you even return to campus!



[Boston University]<http://www.bu.edu/>Boston University
Center for Excellence and Innovation in Teaching
www.bu.edu/ceit<http://www.bu.edu/ceit>

Issues to be addressed in this Teaching Talk were selected based on 56 accumulated journals, written after teaching a foreign language course in the Modern Languages and Comparative Literature department.

Thursday, April 24

What to Do Over the Summer with Blackboard Learn: Kacie Cleary, IS&T, 12:00-1:15 pm

subject: Fwd: IS&T Tech Talk Series: Git/GitHub at Boston University
bodyText:
CNSO folk,

There will be hands on demonstrations of using git version control at
the Photonics Center on March 18.

If you're unfamiliar with version control, or feel like you could stand
to brush up on git, this may be worth your time. It does require
registration: http://www.bu.edu/phpbin/signup/?event_id=131

Chris.

-------- Original Message --------
Subject: 	IS&T Tech Talk Series: Git/GitHub at Boston University
Date: 	Fri, 7 Mar 2014 10:21:25 -0500 (EST)
From: 	donj@bu.edu
To: 	effigies@scc.bu.edu



What:           *IS&T Tech Talk Series:  Git/GitHub at Boston University*

Who:            Firehose Weekend Developers/Trainers, Marco Morawec &
Ken Mazaikawith IS&T contributors Mike Burns, Niall Kavanagh

When:           March 18, 2014 from 11am until 3pm

Where:          8 St. Mary’s Street, Room 339





The March 18^th Tech Talk is devoted to Git/GitHub. The session takes
place from *11 am until 3 pm*. There will be two outside trainers from
Firehose Weekend as well as a presentation by the Applications
Development group. Lunch will be served at 12 o'clock. Enrollment is
limited to 35 attendees. This is hands–on training so attendees are
required to bring a notebook computer or partner with someone who has one.



Please be aware that the Doodle poll we distributed several weeks ago
was /_not_/_registration_.  To register, follow this link:
http://www.bu.edu/phpbin/signup/?event_id=131



Questions can be addressed to Don Johnson (donj@bu.edu
<mailto:donj@bu.edu>), Yann Tambouret (yannpaul@bu.edu
<mailto:yannpaul@bu.edu>) or Pam Andrews (isttech@bu.edu
<mailto:isttech@bu.edu>).

subject: 2/12  Louis Fiore speaks on the Million Veteran Program Big-Data Challenges
bodyText:
[Rafik B. Hariri Institute for Computing and Computational Science & Engineering]<http://www.us6.list-manage2.com/track/click?u=e3ad8f42733d54531fb729327&id=8308e29d72&e=64c9918a14>


Wednesdays @ Hariri<http://www.us6.list-manage1.com/track/click?u=e3ad8f42733d54531fb729327&id=a200ce9e7d&e=64c9918a14>
3 p.m., Feb. 12
Charles River Campus
111 Cummington St., Room 180

We Have a Big Data Problem

Louis Fiore, MD, MPH
Million Veteran Program
The Department of Veterans Affairs

________________________________

Abstract: The Million Veteran Program (MVP) is an effort supported by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to enroll one million Veterans who are active users of the VA healthcare system into a genetic epidemiology cohort. Participants give informed consent and HIPAA authorization for unrestricted use of their electronic medical record (EMR) data and completed case report form (CRF) data for IRB approved research purposes. Additionally, they agree to future re-contact for the purpose of additional data collection and donate a sample of blood for storage and testing. To date approximately 250,000 subjects have been enrolled in MVP from 50 VA Medical Centers participating in the enrollment phase of the study. Recruitment and enrollment of participants into MVP is coordinated by the Massachusetts Veterans Epidemiology and Information Center (MAVERIC) located at the VA Boston Healthcare system.

Informatics support for the MVP is provided by the Genomic Information System for Integrated Science (GenISIS). GenISIS consists of two functionally distinct entities, a Patient Recruitment and Enrollment (PRE) suite of applications and a Scientific Computing Environment (SCE). The PRE was developed by a VA-based informatics core supported by outside contractors and is currently in production to support subject accrual. The SCE is under development and is the focus of the remainder of this white paper.

The functionalities of the SCE include:  loading and warehousing of EMR, case report form and genomic data from VA and laboratory sources, presentation of these data to researchers in a query environment to allow 'preparatory to research' activities, creation of study-specific data marts and provision of analytical pipelines for use by investigators. The intention is to create a platform that allows researchers to approach the MVP data in a governed environment thus eliminating the need to move data to researchers.

Progress to date includes creation of governance and access applications, movement of CRF data into a 'data warehouse', preliminary efforts to extract patient EMR data from the VA Corporate Data Warehouse and installation of an i2b2 query environment. Little progress has been made regarding implementation pipelines or tools to support analysis.

Genomic data from MVP subjects is already arriving. By the end of the 2014 fiscal year (FY) GenISIS will contain genotyping data (Affy Biobank Chip) on approximately 240,000 subjects, whole exome sequencing on 24,000 subjects (from Claritas and Personalis) and whole genome sequencing on 2,400 subjects (Claritas and Personalis). The rate and types of additional genomic data for FY 2015 and beyond is yet to be established but will presumably increase steadily for several years.

The GenISIS team is seeking advice on how to approach two requirements. The first is to create the SCE so that data arriving in FY 2014 can be used by researchers in mid FY 2015. We are focusing on making phenotype and genotype data available for the 240,000 subjects tested with the Affy biobank chip as well as for the 24,000 with whole exome sequence data. The second requirement is to define a long-term solution for storage and compute capability for the full spectrum of phenotype and genotype data that will be made available over the lifetime of the project.

Bio: Louis Fiore is the Executive Director of the Massachusetts Veterans Epidemiology Research and Information Center and of the Million Veteran Program (MVP). He is very interested in utilizing the genetic and electronic medical records system information  from the MVP to provide a large independent confirmatory population to validate specific host cell genetic loci associated with herpes zoster, herpes zoster-associated pain, and postherpetic neuralgia identified in your analysis of data from the Shingles Prevention Study. The MVP should be ideally suited for this purpose, and Lou is happy to collaborate on this important endeavor.

________________________________

To schedule or suggest a talk for future meetings, please send us an email at hicadmin@bu.edu<mailto:hicadmin@bu.edu>.



Forward to a friend<http://us6.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=e3ad8f42733d54531fb729327&id=588fc146a9&e=64c9918a14>

Copyright (c) 2014 Boston University, All rights reserved.
This email is courtesy of the Hariri Institute for Computing.
Our mailing address is:
Boston University
111 Cummington Mall
Boston, MA 02215

[Email Marketing Powered by MailChimp]<http://www.mailchimp.com/monkey-rewards/?utm_source=freemium_newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=monkey_rewards&aid=e3ad8f42733d54531fb729327&afl=1>
bodyHtml:
Wednesdays @ Hariri

3 p.m., Feb. 12

Charles River Campus

111 Cummington St., Room 180 

We Have a Big Data Problem

Louis Fiore, MD, MPH
Million Veteran Program
The Department of Veterans Affairs 

Abstract: The Million Veteran Program (MVP) is an effort supported by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to enroll one million Veterans who are active users of the VA healthcare system into a genetic epidemiology cohort. Participants give informed consent and HIPAA authorization for unrestricted use of their electronic medical record (EMR) data and completed case report form (CRF) data for IRB approved research purposes. Additionally, they agree to future re-contact for the purpose of additional data collection and donate a sample of blood for storage and testing. To date approximately 250,000 subjects have been enrolled in MVP from 50 VA Medical Centers participating in the enrollment phase of the study. Recruitment and enrollment of participants into MVP is coordinated by the Massachusetts Veterans Epidemiology and Information Center (MAVERIC) located at the VA Boston Healthcare system.

Informatics support for the MVP is provided by the Genomic Information System for Integrated Science (GenISIS). GenISIS consists of two functionally distinct entities, a Patient Recruitment and Enrollment (PRE) suite of applications and a Scientific Computing Environment (SCE). The PRE was developed by a VA-based informatics core supported by outside contractors and is currently in production to support subject accrual. The SCE is under development and is the focus of the remainder of this white paper.

The functionalities of the SCE include:  loading and warehousing of EMR, case report form and genomic data from VA and laboratory sources, presentation of these data to researchers in a query environment to allow ‘preparatory to research’ activities, creation of study-specific data marts and provision of analytical pipelines for use by investigators. The intention is to create a platform that allows researchers to approach the MVP data in a governed environment thus eliminating the need to move data to researchers.

Progress to date includes creation of governance and access applications, movement of CRF data into a ‘data warehouse’, preliminary efforts to extract patient EMR data from the VA Corporate Data Warehouse and installation of an i2b2 query environment. Little progress has been made regarding implementation pipelines or tools to support analysis.

Genomic data from MVP subjects is already arriving. By the end of the 2014 fiscal year (FY) GenISIS will contain genotyping data (Affy Biobank Chip) on approximately 240,000 subjects, whole exome sequencing on 24,000 subjects (from Claritas and Personalis) and whole genome sequencing on 2,400 subjects (Claritas and Personalis). The rate and types of additional genomic data for FY 2015 and beyond is yet to be established but will presumably increase steadily for several years.

The GenISIS team is seeking advice on how to approach two requirements. The first is to create the SCE so that data arriving in FY 2014 can be used by researchers in mid FY 2015. We are focusing on making phenotype and genotype data available for the 240,000 subjects tested with the Affy biobank chip as well as for the 24,000 with whole exome sequence data. The second requirement is to define a long-term solution for storage and compute capability for the full spectrum of phenotype and genotype data that will be made available over the lifetime of the project.
  
Bio: Louis Fiore is the Executive Director of the Massachusetts Veterans Epidemiology Research and Information Center and of the Million Veteran Program (MVP). He is very interested in utilizing the genetic and electronic medical records system information  from the MVP to provide a large independent confirmatory population to validate specific host cell genetic loci associated with herpes zoster, herpes zoster-associated pain, and postherpetic neuralgia identified in your analysis of data from the Shingles Prevention Study. The MVP should be ideally suited for this purpose, and Lou is happy to collaborate on this important endeavor.
